Pregnancy and maternity: case decisions
	
	

	

 




Pregnancy and maternity: case decisions






The case decisions below have been grouped by issue e.g.
dismissal so that you can find the section that addresses your area
of interest. These decisions are helpful in informing any
negotiations you intend to have with your employer about your
treatment, helping you decide whether it is likely to be unlawful
or not and in preparing your case for tribunal. Where a case is
relevant to more than one issue, it has been included under each
relevant topic.

 

Decisions at Employment Appeal Tribunal (EAT) and above are
case law which tribunals have to follow in deciding a case once
they have established the facts.

 

Some of the most important cases are decided by the European
Court of Justice (ECJ). The courts in each European Community
country can ask the ECJ to decide how European laws like the Equal
Treatment Directive should be applied.

 

Where the case has been reported in the Industrial Relations
Law Reports (IRLR) the reference has been included in the case
title. IRLR is often available from public libraries. The case
decisions may also be available online from the British and
Irish Legal Information website.

Case decisions by issue:

	Breastfeeding
	Compensation
	Contract workers
	Dismissal
	Employment-related benefits
	Health and safety
	IVF
	Pregnancy, recruitment and promotion
	Pregnancy-related sickness
	Right to return to work
	Issues that apply to all sex discrimination
claims


Breastfeeding

Squillaci v Atkins (1997 ET)

Mrs Squillaci was a
Senior Architectural Technician. Along with other staff she lost
contractual benefits which included flexible working when her local
authority contracted her department out to Atkins. She took
maternity absence from the company and 2 months before her return
date she asked to return part-time so that she could continue
breastfeeding her baby. Because there was a family history of
asthma and the baby had eczema it was preferable for the baby's
health that breastfeeding continue for as long as possible. If she
had to return full time the distance she would have had to travel
to work combined with her hours of work would have meant that she
was absent for 11 hours and at this time the baby was waking
frequently at night. All Mrs Squillaci's proposals for flexible
working were rejected and as she could not return to work full-time
her contract was terminated.

 

Mrs Squillaci argued that the full-time work condition was
indirectly discriminatory and a condition that fewer women than men
could comply with as the primary carer of children. The tribunal
agreed with her and found that her employer had discriminated
against her.


Williams v MOD (2003 EAT)

Mrs Williams was a flight-lieutenant in the RAF. She wanted to
return to work after taking maternity leave, but also wanted to
continue to breastfeed her baby. However, MOD policy required that
any woman returning to work would be expected to be able to fulfil
their full range of duties. The MOD made it clear that this might
well mean that a woman would not be able to continue breastfeeding.
The only other option offered was for a woman to take unpaid
"occupational maternity absence" until she was in a position to
return to her full duties. Mrs Williams felt she could not return
to work under those terms and resigned.

 

The tribunal decided that Mrs Williams had been directly
discriminated against on the basis of her sex. Not only this, but
they stated that she had been automatically
directly discriminated against and therefore did not have to
compare herself with a man in similar circumstances. However, at
the EAT, all the parties accepted that "automatic discrimination"
did not apply beyond the end of maternity leave, so the EAT
overturned the decision, sending it back to the ET to decide
whether Mrs Williams was treated less favourably than a male
comparator had (or would have) been or, alternatively, whether she
had been indirectly discriminated against.

Compensation

Deane v London Borough of Ealing (1993 IRLR 209); MoD v
Meredith (1995 IRLR 539)(EAT)

Damages are compensatory not punitive.



Marshall v Southampton and South West Hampshire Area Health
Authority (No.2)(1993 IRLR 445)(ECJ)

Compensation should make good in full the loss actually
sustained.


Ministry of Defence v Cannock (1994 IRLR 509) (EAT)

Up to 1990, the armed forces had a policy of dismissing
pregnant servicewomen. In 1991, the MOD conceded that this policy
was sexually discriminatory. In this case, the EAT gave guidance on
how compensation should be calculated when a woman has been
unlawfully dismissed due to her pregnancy. The EAT said that in
deciding how much compensation should be awarded for future loss of
earnings, the tribunal has to make an assessment of what would have
happened in the future. In particular, the tribunal must assess as
a percentage the chance that a woman would have returned to work
following maternity leave. For example, if there is a 60% chance
that a woman would have returned to work after maternity leave if
she had not been dismissed, the compensation to be awarded should
be 60% of the earnings she would have received had she
returned.

 

The EAT also said that if the woman would have incurred
childcare costs if she had returned to work, those costs must be
deducted from the earnings she would have received in calculating
compensation.

Vento v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire (2003 IRLR 102)
(Court of Appeal)

In this case (which was not a pregnancy discrimination case)
the Court of Appeal set guidelines for tribunals on how to
calculate compensation for injury to feelings. According to the
Court of Appeal, an award of compensation for injury to feelings
should fall within one of three bands: the top band, covering the
most serious cases, for example where there has been a lengthy
campaign of harassment, should normally be between £15,000 and
£25,000. Only in the most exceptional case should an award of
compensation for injury to feelings exceed £25,000. A middle band
of between £5,000 and £15,000 should be used for serious cases,
which do not merit an award in the highest band. Awards of between
£500 and £5,000 are appropriate for less serious cases, such as
where the act of discrimination is an isolated or one off
occurrence, but awards of less than £500 are to be avoided
altogether, as they risk being regarded as so low as not to be a
proper recognition of injury to feelings

Contract workers

Patefield v Belfast City Council (2000 IRLR 664) (Northern
Ireland Court of Appeal)

The Sex Discrimination Act 1975 (SDA) makes
it unlawful for a company to discriminate against a worker supplied
by another employer to do work for the company, such as an agency
worker. In the SDA, the company for which the work is done in such
a situation is known as the "principal". In this case, Belfast City
Council unlawfully discriminated against an agency worker by
refusing to allow her to return to the post she had been carrying
out before she went on maternity leave. The Council had instead
given the post to a permanent employee while the agency worker was
on maternity leave. The Court of Appeal decided that the Council's
actions amounted to automatic sex discrimination because it would
not have treated the agency worker the way it had but for her
absence on maternity leave.


Caruana v Manchester Airport PLC (1996 IRLR 378)(EAT)

Mrs Caruana was employed by Manchester Airport as an
independent sub-contractor under a series of fixed-term contracts.
When she informed the respondent that she was pregnant, they
decided not to renew her contract because she would be unavailable
for work at the beginning of the next contract.

 

The EAT ruled that it is automatically sex discrimination to
dismiss a woman, or to refuse to renew her fixed-term contract as a
consequence of her pregnancy, regardless of whether a man would not
have his contract renewed due to his unavailability at the
beginning of a new contract. 


BP Chemicals Ltd v (1) Gillick (2) Roevin Management Services
Ltd (1994 IRLR 128)(EAT)

Roevin Management Services, an employment agency, had a
contract with BP Chemicals to supply it with workers. Ms Gillick
was one of those workers. She worked at BP for several years, but
when she stopped working to have a baby, BP did not allow her to
return to her old job. Ms Gillick claimed that her treatment was an
infringement of her rights as an employee under the SDA.

 

The EAT found that there was no contract between BP and Ms
Gillick, so she could not bring a claim under the SDA against BP as
an employee. However, Ms Gillick's could bring a claim against BP
for discriminating against her as a contract worker. Roevin
supplied her services to BP under a contract between Roevin and BP.
This made BP her "principal" and the SDA made it unlawful for them
to discriminate against her.


Dismissal

O'Neill v (1) Governors of Thomas More RCVA (2) Bedfordshire CC
(1996 IRLR 372) (EAT)

Mrs O'Neill taught at a Roman Catholic
voluntary aided school. She became pregnant, and it became public
knowledge that the father of the child was a Roman Catholic priest
who was known in the locality and at the school. She was not
allowed to return to her job after giving birth to her daughter and
claimed sex discrimination and unfair constructive dismissal. Her
employer argued that she was not dismissed because of her
pregnancy, but because of the moral and social implications of her
pregnancy (Mrs O'Neill taught religious education). However, the
EAT said that what mattered was whether Mrs O'Neill's pregnancy was
an effective cause of her dismissal. It clearly was, so her
dismissal was automatically discriminatory.


Hertz v Aldi Marked (1991 IRLR 31) (ECJ)

Mrs Hertz was employed as a part-time cashier and saleswoman.
She was mainly on sick leave during her pregnancy. She returned to
work after her maternity leave ended and had no health problems for
the next 6 months. However, in the following year she had 100 days
sick leave; her illness was directly connected with her pregnancy.
Mrs Hertz's employer dismissed her for repeated absences due to
illness. The Danish courts referred the matter to the ECJ, asking
whether the Equal Treatment Directive provided protection for women
dismissed as a consequence of sickness absence which is pregnancy
and childbirth-related. If it did, the Danish court asked whether
there was any limit on the period for which that protection
applied.

 

The ECJ decided that a woman is protected from dismissal
because of sickness absence during statutory maternity leave but
once the leave is over there is no reason to distinguish a
pregnancy-related illness from any other. The dismissal of a woman
for sickness during pregnancy or maternity leave will be
automatically discriminatory, but her dismissal because of sickness
after her return from maternity leave will only be discriminatory
if it can be shown that a man would have been treated more
favourably. 


Webb v Emo Air Cargo (UK) Ltd (1994 IRLR 482; 1995 IRLR645)
(ECJ)

Mrs Webb was recruited to cover for the maternity leave of
another employee, and it was agreed that she would be kept on after
that employee's return. She began 6 months' training. About two
weeks after beginning work, Mrs Webb told her manager that she
thought that she was pregnant. The employer dismissed her because
she would be unable to cover her colleague's maternity absence. In
their defence, they argued that they would have treated a man/
non-pregnant woman in the same way; it was not the pregnancy that
led to the dismissal but the employee's unavailability for
work.

 

The ECJ decided that the dismissal of a pregnant woman on
account of her pregnancy, or for reasons connected with it, is
automatically sex discrimination without the need for a comparison
with a man, or a non-pregnant and sick employee. Pregnancy cannot
be equated with sickness, or with unavailability for work owing to
sickness.

 

The judgment was endorsed by the House of Lords, which decided
that Marleasing required the wording of the SDA to
be interpreted in line with the Equal Treatment Directive.
Pregnancy dismissal is automatically unlawful sex discrimination
where a woman has been recruited on an unlimited contract,
regardless of whether she has been taken on as a maternity
replacement and would be absent for part of the period she was
recruited to cover for.

Brown v Rentokil (1998 IRLR 445; 1995 IRLR 21; 1992 302)
(ECJ)

Mrs Brown, who was a service driver, became pregnant and
shortly afterwards went off sick with pregnancy
complications.

 

She was dismissed in accordance with the employer's sickness
policy that allowed no more than 26 weeks' continuous absence. This
policy applied regardless of sex. As the law stood at the time of
her dismissal, Mrs Brown was not protected against dismissal on the
grounds of pregnancy. (This was before the ERA was amended to give
all women protection against pregnancy-related dismissal
irrespective of length of service.) Mrs Brown argued that her
treatment was unlawful under the SDA and/or the ETD, regardless of
whether a man would be dismissed for a similar period of sickness
absence, because her sickness absence was for pregnancy-related
reasons. The ECJ upheld Mrs Brown's claim, and ruled that to
dismiss a woman for pregnancy-related sickness while she is
pregnant is unlawful; the ECJ also said that it would be unlawful
to take into account time off for pregnancy-related sickness while
pregnant in calculating sickness absence when deciding to dismiss a
woman for sickness absence after her return from maternity leave.



Caledonia Bureau Investment & Property v Caffrey (1998 IRLR
110) (EAT)

Mrs Caffrey was unable to return to work after maternity leave
because she was suffering from post-natal depression. She submitted
sick certificates covering her absence, but her employer dismissed
her on the grounds of her absence due to illness. Mrs Caffrey
argued that she had been unfairly dismissed and had suffered sex
discrimination. The EAT said that since a man could not suffer from
a pregnancy-related illness, to dismiss a woman for a reason
connected with such an illness, even after her maternity leave has
ended, is sex discrimination. The dismissal was also an
automatically unfair dismissal, because it was a dismissal
connected with Mrs Caffrey's pregnancy. [This decision has been
criticised because it seems inconsistent with the decision of the
ECJ in the Hertz case.]

Rees v Apollo Watch Repairs plc (1996 ICR 466)(EAT)

Mrs Rees was a receptionist. She was refused her job back
after her maternity leave because the employer preferred the woman
they had taken on to cover for her as they found her to be more
efficient. Mrs Rees argued that her dismissal was a direct
consequence of her pregnancy and absence on maternity leave. Had
she not been absent her employer would not have found a
replacement. The EAT said that dismissing a woman on maternity
leave because her maternity replacement was found to be more
efficient was direct sex discrimination following
Webb, since the underlying cause of dismissal
arose from her absence on maternity leave.


Berry v The Potter Group Ltd (1999 ET)

Mrs Berry was taken on as a warehouse operative on a temporary
contract to cover for a maternity leaver. She accepted an offer of
a part-time permanent job, but this was withdrawn and she was
dismissed for being absent at the start of the new contract. She
had suffered an ectopic pregnancy and would have been on unpaid
sickness absence for approximately 10 weeks. The tribunal found
that Mrs Berry had been dismissed for a reason connected with her
ectopic pregnancy and that this was automatically unfair sex
discrimination.


Employment-related benefits

GUS Home Shopping Ltd v Green and McLaughlin (2001 IRLR 75)
(EAT)

Mrs McLaughlin and Mrs Green were employed
in the marketing department of GUS, based in Worcester. GUS decided
to relocate the marketing department to Manchester, making some
employees redundant. The company introduced a discretionary loyalty
bonus to ensure the smooth transfer of the undertaking. Eligibility
was based on the employee demonstrating cooperation and goodwill,
remaining in post to an agreed date, and the orderly and effective
transfer of the undertaking in the preceding 6 months. Mrs
McLaughlin and Mrs Green did not receive any loyalty payment, the
former owing to her absence on maternity leave throughout the
relevant period and the latter for her absence for part of the
relevant period for a combination of pregnancy-related sickness and
maternity leave reasons.

 

The EAT upheld the tribunal's decision that the employer had
discriminated against the two women by disqualifying them from the
bonus because they were absent from work during the relevant period
for pregnancy and maternity-related reasons. The House of Lords in
Webb (no.2) suggested that the usual rule in
Webb (discussed under "Dismissal" above) would not
apply where a woman would be absent on maternity leave for the
whole of the period of the contract for which she was engaged. GUS
had argued that the loyalty bonus was a separate contract from the
main employment contract, with a definite payment for a definite
purpose for a definite period. They claimed that because Mrs Green
and Mrs McLaughlin were absent for the whole of the period of that
"separate contract", the exception to Webb
applied, and it was not discriminatory to refuse to pay them the
loyalty bonus. The EAT held that the tribunal had correctly decided
that this case did not fall within the exception. The loyalty bonus
was part and parcel of Mrs Green and Mrs McLaughlin's employment
contracts, not a separate contract. Since they would not be absent
on maternity leave for the whole of the period of their employment
contract, it was sex discrimination to refuse to pay them the
bonus.


Pedersen v Kvickly Skive (1999 IRLR 55)(ECJ)

Mrs Pedersen experienced a difficult pregnancy and was unfit
for work due to illness before maternity leave. Under Danish law
employees who are absent from work owing to illness are entitled to
full pay. However, there are different provisions for pregnant
workers. A pregnant employee who is ill is entitled to full pay
only if the illness is unconnected with pregnancy. According to
these rules Mrs Pedersen was not entitled to full pay, because her
illness was connected with her pregnancy. In accordance with Danish
law, she was suspended on half pay. The ECJ held that it is
automatically sex discrimination to exclude a pregnant woman who
has not yet started her maternity leave from a sick pay scheme,
even if her sickness is pregnancy related. However, it is not
discriminatory to refuse to pay sick pay to a woman who is absent
from work due to "inconveniences" (rather than sickness) related to
her pregnancy. The ECJ also held that where a woman has been
suspended from work for health and safety reasons because no
suitable work is available for her, it is discriminatory not to pay
her full pay while suspended.


Alabaster v (1) Woolwich PLC (2) Secretary of State for Social
Security (2004 IRLR 486)(ECJ)

Ms Alabaster worked as an administrator for the building
society. She took maternity leave in January '96. Her pay rise,
awarded to her in December, was not included in her maternity pay.
This was because it was awarded outside the eight week calculation
period (the reference period) for determining the earnings-related
part of statutory maternity pay.

 

She argued that this breached the Equal Pay Act 1970 (EqPA)
and European Law, which has established the principle that a woman
should benefit from any pay rise "which is awarded between the
beginning of the period covered by reference pay and the end of
maternity leave."

 

The Court of Appeal asked the ECJ to decide whether European
law meant that Mrs Alabaster's pay-rise should be taken into
account in calculating her maternity pay and, if so, how that
calculation should be worked out.

 

In March 2004, the ECJ confirmed that Ms Alabaster's pay rise
should have been taken into account in calculating her maternity
pay. However, the ECJ said it was for the UK Government to decide
how the law should be changed to implement this. The case will go
back to the Court of Appeal, which will have to decide whether Ms
Alabaster's claim to recover the underpayment of maternity pay
should have been brought under the EqPA or as a claim for deduction
of wages under the ERA.


Health and safety

Pedersen v Kvickly Skive (1999 IRLR 55)(ECJ)

Mrs Pedersen experienced a difficult
pregnancy and was unfit for work due to illness before maternity
leave. Under Danish law employees who are absent from work owing to
illness are entitled to full pay. However, there are different
provisions for pregnant workers. A pregnant employee who is ill is
entitled to full pay only if the illness is unconnected with
pregnancy. According to these rules Mrs Pedersen was not entitled
to full pay, because her illness was connected with her pregnancy.
In accordance with Danish law, she was suspended on half pay. The
ECJ held that it is automatically sex discrimination to exclude a
pregnant woman who has not yet started her maternity leave from a
sick pay scheme, even if her sickness is pregnancy related.
However, it is not discriminatory to refuse to pay sick pay to a
woman who is absent from work due to "inconveniences" (rather than
sickness) related to her pregnancy. The ECJ also held that where a
woman has been suspended from work for health and safety reasons
because no suitable work is available for her, it is discriminatory
not to pay her full pay while suspended.

Johnson v Kauffman (ET 1999)

Mrs Johnson, a senior hair stylist, could not stand for long
periods because she was pregnant. As a result, she asked not to
work the late night opening at the salon. Her employer: tried to
reduce her pay and days worked; deducted pay for her ante natal
visit; insisted on flexible rostering of lunch breaks so she was
invariably on lates; gave her insufficient rest breaks; banned
husbands from collecting spouses from the staff room, made her
sweep up outside the shop; issued her with disciplinary warnings.
Mrs Johnson's GP had provided a medical certificate on which she
wrote that though fit for work, Mrs Johnson should not stand for
prolonged periods owing to pregnancy. She had to produce an
additional medical report when the employer refused the
certificate. The tribunal decided that the above were acts of
unlawful sex discrimination. In addition, they examined the
respondent's completed risk assessment form and found that it made
no reference to women of childbearing age, that it was dated two
months after Mrs Johnson's pregnancy was known about and that it
paid retrospective lip service to health and safety regulations.
The regulations had been breached in the failure to: carry out a
risk assessment of women in child bearing age; conduct a risk
assessment on Mrs Johnson, which was not dependent on written
notice of pregnancy, and the failure to act on the risk assessment
on receipt of the written notice of the pregnancy.


Hickey v Lucas Service UK Limited (ET 1997)

Mrs Hickey, a delivery driver, was disciplined for poor work
performance and moved to warehouse stores assistant duties, a job
of equivalent pay and status as a driver, but which involved heavy
lifting. The tribunal said, "The employer clearly has a duty to
inform itself of the risks to workers generally and to pregnant
workers in particular and to take appropriate action." Mrs Hickey's
concerns about risks to her pregnancy had not been expressed very
clearly initially, but they were genuine and the Regional Managers
response that she "exercise common sense" and be responsible for
not taking on inappropriate tasks, breached health and safety
requirements. These requirements were to conduct general risk
assessments on the driver and stores assistant posts as well as
assessments specific to Mrs Hickey and her pregnancy.

 

Mrs Hickey had absented herself from work because of her
concerns and had received statutory sick pay prior to returning to
the more suitable post given to her by her employer in response to
her health and safety concerns. The tribunal found that the period
in question amounted to a suspension on health and safety grounds
and the failure to pay her full pay also breached health and safety
regulations.


Mahlburg v Land Mecklenburg-Vorpommern (2000 IRLR 276)
(ECJ)

Ms Mahlburg was a nurse working on a year's fixed-term
contract in a heart surgery clinic. She became pregnant. She
applied for permanent employment as a theatre nurse, which would
have involved her in preparing and handling instruments during
operations. She was rejected on the grounds of her pregnancy
because German health and safety law prohibits the employment of
pregnant women in circumstances that would be hazardous. Ms
Mahlburg claimed that this was sex discrimination contrary to
European law.

 

The ECJ held that refusing to appoint a pregnant woman to a
permanent contract because of a statutory requirement prohibiting
employment for health and safety reasons for the duration of a
pregnancy, is in breach of the Equal Treatment Directive. This is
notwithstanding the clause in the Directive enabling protective
measures for pregnancy and maternity reasons. The ECJ held that
health and safety measures must not give rise to less favourable
treatment of pregnant women in access to jobs as this would
represent a fundamental breach of the principle of equality in the
Directive.

 

The ECJ also ruled that an employer couldn't justify pregnancy
discrimination in recruitment on the ground of financial loss
arising from the inability to employ a woman in a particular post
for the duration of her pregnancy.


Day v T Pickles Farms Ltd (1999 IRLR 217) (EAT)

Mrs Day was a counter assistant at a sandwich shop where
chickens were roasted on the premises twice daily. Mrs Day had
severe morning sickness. She told her employer about her pregnancy
and that the smell of food made her feel sick while at work. She
went on prolonged certificated sick leave during which time she
kept in telephone contact with the employer. Mrs Day's employer
paid her statutory sick pay until her entitlement was exhausted.
Mrs Day then resigned and claimed constructive dismissal, the
failure to pay her statutory sick pay being the last straw. The
employer's failure to carry out a risk assessment was also a chief
feature in her constructive dismissal claim, as was the refusal to
allow her paid time off for antenatal care.

 

Mrs Day's claim of constructive dismissal failed, as she had
not made it plain to her employer that she considered herself to
have been constructively dismissed by his actions. However, the EAT
found that failure to carry out a risk assessment in relation to
women of childbearing age (as the health and safety regulations
require) could constitute sex discrimination, if it results in a
detriment to the employee.


Hardman v Mallon (trading as Orchard Lodge Nursing Home) (2002
IRLR 516) (EAT)

Ms Hardman worked as a care assistant at the Orchard lodge
Nursing Home. Her job involved some lifting of residents and when
she found out she was pregnant, she was concerned that the lifting
could pose a risk to her and her unborn child. She raised her
concerns with her employer, but her employer failed to carry out an
assessment of the risks posed to her and her baby by her working
conditions. At the tribunal, her employer argued that the failure
to carry out a risk assessment could not be sex discrimination
because the employer had not carried out an assessment of the risks
posed to male workers by their working conditions. She argued that
this meant that Ms Hardman had not been treated less favourably
than her male colleagues.

 

The EAT noted that the Management of Health and Safety at Work
Regulations require a specific assessment of the risks posed to new
and expectant mothers by their working conditions. It said that a
failure to carry out such a risk assessment was automatically sex
discrimination, regardless of whether a risk assessment had been
carried out in relation to male employees.

Iske v P & O Ferries (1997 IRLR 401)(EAT)

Mrs Iske was a seagoing stewardess working in the perfume shop
on board of the Pride of Bruges ferry, on the Dover to Calais
route. Her employment was subject to merchant shipping regulations,
which prohibit pregnant women from working at sea after 28 weeks of
pregnancy until at least 6 weeks after delivery. Mrs Iske became
pregnant and hoped that she would be able to work up to 2 weeks
before the birth and that she would be found work on shore.
However, no steps were taken to find her alternative employment,
although alternative work on shore had been found for a man and for
a woman under 28 weeks pregnant, who were temporarily unfit for sea
duties. Mrs Iske was compelled to take maternity leave with
statutory maternity pay straight away, because of the
regulations.

 

Mrs Iske claimed that the company's failure to find her
alternative work, to suspend her on full pay (as required by health
and safety regulations) or to pay her full sick pay was direct sex
discrimination in breach of the SDA and European law. The employer
argued that because pregnancy was a unique condition without
comparison, Mrs Iske could not use a man as her chosen comparator.
It also argued that she had no contractual right to work on shore
nor any statutory rights as merchant shipping was excluded from
health and safety regulations.

 

The EAT upheld her appeal. It decided that the tribunal had
been wrong in finding that her male comparator, a sick man, was an
irrelevant comparison for a pregnant woman. Although the situation
of a pregnant woman cannot be compared with that of a sick man in
deciding whether there is less favourable treatment, comparison of
the way Mrs Iske was treated with the way a man was treated was
relevant evidence in deciding whether the reason
Mrs Iske was treated less favourably was her pregnancy. Mrs Iske
had not been offered a transfer, while other non-pregnant employees
(including men) had been transferred. The EAT accepted that this
was evidence from which they could infer that the reason Mrs Iske
was not transferred was because she was over 28 weeks
pregnant.

 

The EAT also said that failure to bring merchant shipping
regulations within the scope of health and safety regulations was a
breach by the UK Government of the Pregnant Workers' Directive. The
law has subsequently been amended to bring this work in scope to
the relevant health and safety regulations.


Tapp v The Chief Constable of Suffolk (1998 ET)

Miss Tapp was a probationer police constable. She did not know
it, but she was pregnant at the time of her appointment. Recruits
had to follow a two-year prescribed structured training programme
during which time the group stayed together at local and district
training schools. Five weeks into her training Miss Tapp found out
that she was pregnant and obtained her GP's view that she could
continue with the physical aspects of her training. However, her
employer removed her from training and assigned her to
administrative duties where the quality of the work was less
satisfying, and on her return from maternity leave she would have
to start her training all over again. The tribunal held that there
had been a breach of the SDA in removing Miss Tapp from an
important training course because of pregnancy, which effectively
brought her career to a halt, when a risk assessment would have
shown that this was not necessary.


IVF

London Borough of Greenwich v Robinson (1995 EAT)

Ms Robinson was a highly qualified and
experienced psychiatric social worker within the Child Guidance
Unit of the Borough.

During her employment she underwent 2 unsuccessful courses of
IVF treatment, which were classed as sickness absence. The council
sought to reduce its workforce with a redundancy programme. Ms
Robinson took voluntary redundancy under duress because her manager
had decided to base the selection decision on sickness absence
only, excluding other criteria, which would have made her
vulnerable to compulsory redundancy on less favourable terms.

 

Ms Robinson argued unfair selection for redundancy and direct
and/or indirect sex discrimination. The tribunal decided that Ms
Robinson had been unfairly selected for redundancy because her
employer had disregarded other criteria. However, the sex
discrimination claims failed on the grounds that men could undergo
fertility treatment and would be treated in the same way as regards
calculating sickness absence for redundancy purposes. The absences
were for medical treatment and could not in this case be deemed to
be pregnancy-related (see Webb which is discussed
above under "Dismissal") nor was it appropriate to single out
particular types of sickness from the sickness record criterion for
the detrimental impact they might have on one sex compared with the
other in the redundancy stakes.


Pregnancy,
recruitment and promotion

Dekker v VJV-Centrum (1991 IRLR 27) (ECJ)

Mrs Dekker applied for a post as a training
instructor in a youth centre. She informed the selection committee
that she was pregnant. The committee recommended her as the most
suitable candidate for appointment, but the employer decided not to
recruit her because they would not have been reimbursed for
benefits paid to her during maternity leave under the Dutch
system.

 

The case was referred to the ECJ by the Dutch courts. Two of
the issues they were asked to address were: whether an employer is
in breach of the Equal Treatment Directive (ETD) where he refuses
employment to a pregnant woman because of the possible adverse
consequences to him arising from the fact that she is pregnant;
whether, despite having violated the ETD, the employer can then
rely on the defence of legal justification under national
law.

 

The ECJ's decision was that the ETD gives automatic protection
to a pregnant woman who is refused a job because of financial
consequences of her maternity absence (in this case, the
administration of maternity benefits). Since pregnancy is unique to
women, refusal of employment connected with pregnancy is
automatically sex discrimination, regardless of how a man would
have been treated in the same circumstances. The ECJ also decided
that the law did not allow the employer to justify such direct
discrimination.


Mahlburg v Land Mecklenburg-Vorpommern (2000 IRLR 276)
(ECJ)

Ms Mahlburg was a nurse working on a year's fixed-term
contract in a heart surgery clinic. She became pregnant. She
applied for permanent employment as a theatre nurse, which would
have involved her in preparing and handling instruments during
operations. She was rejected on the grounds of her pregnancy
because German health and safety law prohibits the employment of
pregnant women in circumstances that would be hazardous. Ms
Mahlburg claimed that this was sex discrimination contrary to
European law.

 

The ECJ held that refusing to appoint a pregnant woman to a
permanent contract because of a statutory requirement prohibiting
employment for health and safety reasons for the duration of a
pregnancy, is in breach of the Equal Treatment Directive. This is
notwithstanding the clause in the Directive enabling protective
measures for pregnancy and maternity reasons. The ECJ held that
health and safety measures must not give rise to less favourable
treatment of pregnant women in access to jobs as this would
represent a fundamental breach of the principle of equality in the
Directive.

 

The ECJ also ruled that an employer couldn't justify pregnancy
discrimination in recruitment on the ground of financial loss
arising from the inability to employ a woman in a particular post
for the duration of her pregnancy.

CNAVTS v Thibault (1998 IRLR 399) (ECJ)

Ms Thibault was employed as a legal drafter by the French
civil service. Promotion rules were determined by a national
collective agreement which provided that an employee who had been
present at work for at least 6 months must be assessed on their
work and conduct; qualifying for promotion was subject to such an
assessment. Ms Thibault could not meet the '6 month rule' due to a
combination of sick leave and several months' maternity leave. Her
employer did not assess her performance and she complained of sex
discrimination.

 

The ECJ ruled that the right to an annual performance
assessment, which might lead to a promotion, was an integral part
of working conditions, which the Equal Treatment Directive requires
be provided on an equal basis to men and women. To deny a woman
employee the right to have her performance assessed annually would
discriminate against her in her capacity as a worker because, if
she had not been pregnant and had not taken maternity leave to
which she was entitled, she would have been assessed for the year
in question and could have qualified for promotion.

Greenfield v (1) Ian MacAuley (2) Westward Babywear Ltd (2000
ET)

Ms Greenfield was the company's Financial Accountant,
reporting to the Financial Director. She went on maternity leave in
September '98. Mr Strachan, a qualified Chartered Accountant, was
appointed to cover her maternity leave. He was then promoted to a
newly created more senior post above Ms Greenfield. Ms Greenfield
was informed of the changes made in her absence on the day she
returned from her maternity leave. She resigned because of her
treatment and claimed sex discrimination.

 

The tribunal found that Ms Greenfield had been unfairly
dismissed and suffered unlawful sex discrimination: Ms Greenfield's
access to promotion had been hindered by the fact that she had not
been considered because she was on maternity leave at the time that
consideration was given to the creation of a new post. The tribunal
also found that the appointment of Mr Strachan above her and
between her and the Finance Director also hindered her prospects of
promotion. The tribunal concluded that Ms Greenfield's loss of
status and changes imposed on her without any consultation upon her
return from maternity leave, amounted to subjecting her to a
detriment.


Visa International Service Association v Paul (2004 IRLR
42)(EAT)

Mrs Paul worked in the card design section of Visa's operating
regulations services department. She took maternity leave in July
2000. Before doing so, she had expressed an interest in moving to
the dispute resolution section within the same department. While
Mrs Paul was on maternity leave, Visa re-organised the department,
creating two new posts. The tribunal found that Mrs Paul was not
told about the vacancies because she was on maternity leave.

 

Mrs Paul claimed that the failure to keep her informed about
developments in her department while she was on maternity leave was
sex discrimination and a breach of the implied term of good faith
in her employment contract. She claimed that the breach was serious
enough to justify her resigning and claiming constructive
dismissal, and that that dismissal was automatically unfair under
s.99 of ERA because it was related to her maternity leave.

 

The ET agreed with Mrs Paul and found that Visa's failure to
keep her informed of developments during her maternity leave was
unlawful sex discrimination and also breached her contract of
employment to such an extent that she could claim constructive
dismissal. Because that dismissal was related to her maternity
leave, it was automatically unfair. The EAT upheld the ET's
decision.

Pregnancy-related sickness

Hertz v Aldi Marked (1991 IRLR 31) (ECJ)

Mrs Hertz was employed as a part-time
cashier and saleswoman. She was mainly on sick leave during her
pregnancy. She returned to work after her maternity leave ended and
had no health problems for the next 6 months. However, in the
following year she had 100 days sick leave; her illness was
directly connected with her pregnancy. Mrs Hertz's employer
dismissed her for repeated absences due to illness. The Danish
courts referred the matter to the ECJ, asking whether the Equal
Treatment Directive provided protection for women dismissed as a
consequence of sickness absence which is pregnancy and
childbirth-related. If it did, the Danish court asked whether there
was any limit on the period for which that protection
applied.

 

The ECJ decided that a woman is protected from dismissal
because of sickness absence during statutory maternity leave but
once the leave is over there is no reason to distinguish a
pregnancy-related illness from any other. The dismissal of a woman
for sickness during pregnancy or maternity leave will be
automatically discriminatory, but her dismissal because of sickness
after her return from maternity leave will only be discriminatory
if it can be shown that a man would have been treated more
favourably.


Pedersen v Kvickly Skive (1999 IRLR 55)(ECJ)

Mrs Pedersen experienced a difficult pregnancy and was unfit
for work due to illness before maternity leave. Under Danish law
employees who are absent from work owing to illness are entitled to
full pay. However, there are different provisions for pregnant
workers. A pregnant employee who is ill is entitled to full pay
only if the illness is unconnected with pregnancy. According to
these rules Mrs Pedersen was not entitled to full pay, because her
illness was connected with her pregnancy. In accordance with Danish
law, she was suspended on half pay. The ECJ held that it is
automatically sex discrimination to exclude a pregnant woman who
has not yet started her maternity leave from a sick pay scheme,
even if her sickness is pregnancy related. However, it is not
discriminatory to refuse to pay sick pay to a woman who is absent
from work due to "inconveniences" (rather than sickness) related to
her pregnancy. The ECJ also held that where a woman has been
suspended from work for health and safety reasons because no
suitable work is available for her, it is discriminatory not to pay
her full pay while suspended.


Caledonia Bureau Investment & Property v Caffrey (1998 IRLR
110) (EAT)

Mrs Caffrey was unable to return to work after maternity leave
because she was suffering from post-natal depression. She submitted
sick certificates covering her absence, but her employer dismissed
her on the grounds of her absence due to illness. Mrs Caffrey
argued that she had been unfairly dismissed and had suffered sex
discrimination. The EAT said that since a man could not suffer from
a pregnancy-related illness, to dismiss a woman for a reason
connected with such an illness, even after her maternity leave has
ended, is sex discrimination. The dismissal was also an
automatically unfair dismissal, because it was a dismissal
connected with Mrs Caffrey's pregnancy. [This decision has been
criticised because it seems inconsistent with the decision of the
ECJ in the Hertz case.]

Brown v Rentokil (1998 IRLR 445; 1995 IRLR 21; 1992 302)
(ECJ)

Mrs Brown, who was a service driver, became pregnant and
shortly afterwards went off sick with pregnancy
complications.

 

She was dismissed in accordance with the employer's sickness
policy that allowed no more than 26 weeks' continuous absence. This
policy applied regardless of sex. As the law stood at the time of
her dismissal, Mrs Brown was not protected against dismissal on the
grounds of pregnancy. (This was before the ERA was amended to give
all women protection against pregnancy-related dismissal
irrespective of length of service.) Mrs Brown argued that her
treatment was unlawful under the SDA and/or the ETD, regardless of
whether a man would be dismissed for a similar period of sickness
absence, because her sickness absence was for pregnancy-related
reasons. The ECJ upheld Mrs Brown's claim, and ruled that to
dismiss a woman for pregnancy-related sickness while she is
pregnant is unlawful; the ECJ also said that it would be unlawful
to take into account time off for pregnancy-related sickness while
pregnant in calculating sickness absence when deciding to dismiss a
woman for sickness absence after her return from maternity leave.



Right to return to
work

Greenfield v (1) Ian MacAuley (2) Westward Babywear Ltd (2000
ET)

Ms Greenfield was the company's Financial
Accountant, reporting to the Financial Director. She went on
maternity leave in September '98. Mr Strachan, a qualified
Chartered Accountant, was appointed to cover her maternity leave.
He was then promoted to a newly created more senior post above Ms
Greenfield. Ms Greenfield was informed of the changes made in her
absence on the day she returned from her maternity leave. She
resigned because of her treatment and claimed sex
discrimination.

 

The tribunal found that Ms Greenfield had been unfairly
dismissed and suffered unlawful sex discrimination: Ms Greenfield's
access to promotion had been hindered by the fact that she had not
been considered because she was on maternity leave at the time that
consideration was given to the creation of a new post. The tribunal
also found that the appointment of Mr Strachan above her and
between her and the Finance Director also hindered her prospects of
promotion. The tribunal concluded that Ms Greenfield's loss of
status and changes imposed on her without any consultation upon her
return from maternity leave, amounted to subjecting her to a
detriment.


Squillaci v Atkins (1997 ET)

Mrs Squillaci was a Senior Architectural Technician. Along
with other staff she lost contractual benefits which included
flexible working when her local authority contracted her department
out to Atkins. She took maternity absence from the company and 2
months before her return date she asked to return part-time so that
she could continue breastfeeding her baby. Because there was a
family history of asthma and the baby had eczema it was preferable
for the baby's health that breastfeeding continue for as long as
possible. If she had to return full time the distance she would
have had to travel to work combined with her hours of work would
have meant that she was absent for 11 hours and at this time the
baby was waking frequently at night. All Mrs Squillaci's proposals
for flexible working were rejected and as she could not return to
work full-time her contract was terminated.

 

Mrs Squillaci argued that the full-time work condition was
indirectly discriminatory and a condition that fewer women than men
could comply with as the primary carer of children. The tribunal
agreed with her and found that her employer had discriminated
against her.

Williams v MOD

Mrs Williams was a flight-lieutenant in the RAF. She wanted to
return to work after taking maternity leave, but also wanted to
continue to breastfeed her baby. However, MOD policy required that
any woman returning to work would be expected to be able to fulfil
their full range of duties. The MOD made it clear that this might
well mean that a woman would not be able to continue breastfeeding.
The only other option offered was for a woman to take unpaid
"occupational maternity absence" until she was in a position to
return to her full duties. Mrs Williams felt she could not return
to work under those terms and resigned.

 

The tribunal decided that Mrs Williams had been directly
discriminated against on the basis of her sex. Not only this, but
they stated that she had been automatically
directly discriminated against and therefore did not have to
compare herself with a man in similar circumstances. However, at
the EAT, all the parties accepted that "automatic discrimination"
did not apply beyond the end of maternity leave, so the EAT
overturned the decision, sending it back to the ET to decide
whether Mrs Williams was treated less favourably than a male
comparator had (or would have) been or, alternatively, whether she
had been indirectly discriminated against.

Rees v Apollo Watch Repairs plc (1996 ICR 466)(EAT)

Mrs Rees was a receptionist. She was refused her job back
after her maternity leave because the employer preferred the woman
they had taken on to cover for her as they found her to be more
efficient. Mrs Rees argued that her dismissal was a direct
consequence of her pregnancy and absence on maternity leave. Had
she not been absent her employer would not have found a
replacement. The EAT held that dismissing a woman on maternity
leave because her maternity replacement was found to be more
efficient was direct sex discrimination following
Webb, since the underlying cause of dismissal
arose from her absence on maternity leave.


Issues that apply to
all sex discrimination claims

King v Great Britain-China Centre (1991 IRLR 513)(Court of
Appeal)

The claimant must make out a case on the
balance of probabilities. It is then for the employer to provide a
satisfactory explanation, in the absence of which it is reasonable
to infer discrimination. There is unlikely to be direct evidence of
discrimination. The outcome of a case will depend on inferences
drawn from the primary facts, including an inference of
discrimination from a failure to reply to a questionnaire, or an
evasive or equivocal reply. This approach is now reflected in the
SDA as a result of the Sex Discrimination (Indirect Discrimination
and Burden of Proof) Regulations 2001.

Barton v Investec Henderson Crosthwaite Securities (2003 IRLR
332) (EAT)

In this case the EAT gave guidelines to tribunals on how to
apply the Sex Discrimination (Indirect Discrimination and Burden of
Proof) Regulations 2001. If the tribunal find facts from which they
could infer that the reason for the less favourable treatment of a
woman could have been sex discrimination, the tribunal is obliged
to find in favour of the woman unless the employer can put satisfy
them that there is another non-discriminatory explanation for the
less favourable treatment.


James v Eastleigh Borough Council (1990 IRLR 288)(House of
Lords)

Intention and motive are irrelevant when deciding whether
discrimination has taken place. The objective test for determining
this is, whether "but for" your sex, would you have received the
same treatment.


Marleasing SA v LA Comercial Internacional de Alimentacion SA
(1990 1ECR 435; 1992 1 CMLR 305) (ECJ)

Where possible, UK courts and tribunals must interpret
domestic legislation in a way that complies with European Community
law. This means that the SDA must be read in such a way that it is
consistent with the principles and intentions of the Equal
Treatment Directive (ETD). Because the ETD is broader in scope than
the SDA, this means that bringing a claim under the ETD as well as
the SDA can sometimes improve its prospects of
success.


Webb v Emo Air Cargo (UK) Ltd (1994 IRLR 482; 1995 IRLR645)
(ECJ)

Mrs Webb was recruited to cover for the maternity leave of
another employee, and it was agreed that she would be kept on after
that employee's return. She began 6 months' training. About two
weeks after beginning work, Mrs Webb told her manager that she
thought that she was pregnant. The employer dismissed her because
she would be unable to cover her colleague's maternity absence. In
their defence, they argued that they would have treated a man/
non-pregnant woman in the same way; it was not the pregnancy that
led to the dismissal but the employee's unavailability for
work.

 

The ECJ decided that the dismissal of a pregnant woman on
account of her pregnancy, or for reasons connected with it, is
automatically sex discrimination without the need for a comparison
with a man, or a non-pregnant and sick employee. Pregnancy cannot
be equated with sickness, or with unavailability for work owing to
sickness.

 

The judgment was endorsed by the House of Lords , which
decided that Marleasing required the wording of
the SDA to be interpreted in line with the Equal Treatment
Directive. Pregnancy dismissal is automatically unlawful sex
discrimination where a woman has been recruited on an unlimited
contract, regardless of whether she has been taken on as a
maternity replacement and would be absent for part of the period
she was recruited to cover for.

									Speech by Ivan Lewis MP, Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Care Services, 22 June 2006: Third Sector Summit

				
						
				
					Last modified date:
				

				
					8 February 2007
				

		


				

		Good morning everybody, I am really delighted to have the opportunity to be here at this really important and groundbreaking conference.

								

											
						Lynne (Berry, GSCC), it is good to see you again. I spent Monday with you this week, Tuesday with you this week and now Thursday morning. Yesterday was a little sad from my point of view, but I am delighted to be here with you.
	This is a very, very significant conference and I have been asked today to talk about specifically the Third sector, in the context of what we are trying to do at DH and in the context of the kind of society this government is seeking to create. A society which is strengthened on the dual, and inextricably linked, foundations of both social justice and of economic success, and there is a recognition in that context that we can only build such a society if we have all the contributors to that society playing their equal part and fulfilling their responsibilities.
	I myself, before I came into politics, spent my entire working life in the voluntary sector. I was recently introduced at a conference as having been elected to parliament in 1977, which would have made me 10. I was actually elected to parliament in 1997 and before that I had spent my entire working life in the Third Sector. I think this is an important point to make at a conference like this where politicians arrive in a suit, make their pre-prepared speech, leave again and people somehow feel there is a disconnect between politics and the issues we are here to talk about. Well most politicians actually have a significant hinterland before they entered the formal world of politics.
	I began my role at the age of 14; I was at a secondary school, expected to do traditional GCSEs or perhaps O Levels as they were in those days, go and do some A-Levels, go to University and get a proper job. My parents are still waiting, I think, for that to happen.
	But I got involved in voluntary work at the age of 14 through school, with people with Learning Disabilities. That very much started to shape the type of career I wanted to have, at the age of 16 or 17. I didn't say this when I was an Education Minister -? I lost interest in formal education and decided that really I wanted to work in the voluntary sector. So I went briefly to work for the organisation I did voluntary work with. At the age of 18 I joined with some colleagues and developed a small voluntary organisation literally from scratch. Initially all the people involved were doing it all on a voluntary basis - again working with people with Learning Disabilities and people with mental health problems.
	We were then fortunate enough to get a small amount of Government funding (I find this quite ironic because it was through Opportunities for Volunteering funding, which I now make decisions about),? and we had enough money to employ one paid worker. I was very fortunate at the age of 18 or 19 to secure that job, and it was my responsibility to develop that organisation from day one, from scratch.
	Doing the administration, the fundraising, working directly with users and carers, organising the activities, meeting with other professionals, begging statutory organisations to take us seriously and give us a little bit of funding - all of that range of responsibilities and experiences was extremely exciting at the age of 19. A lot of young people became involved in that organisation - some people having finished their university degrees, not sure what to do with their lives, some people taking a gap-year - and many of these people, who are no longer that young, are now involved in care services of one kind or an other.
	I then went to work at a much larger charitable organisation in Manchester providing a culturally sensitive service specifically to the Jewish community; then I became CE of that organisation after about 18 months.? It was an organisation very different to the one I had created and set up with other people. It was 125 years old, it had lost its way a little bit, needed pretty radical reform, thought it was doing a wonderful job, but its only problem was its users and community didn't think it was doing a particularly responsive job, and we had to develop and transform that organisation.
	During this same period I spent 4 years as chair of my Local Authority's social services committee, having been elected to the Local Authority.
	So my experiences in the Third Sector have been very transformational, in terms of the choices I have made and the experiences I have had in my life; and there is absolutely no question that, when I reflect on those organisations and what the key was, it was not the activities and the provisions, but it was the values that underpinned the work of those organisations which motivated the volunteers and the professional staff who want to make an exceptional contribution. I think this question of values is incredibly important. I also believe, however, not all but in many of the services we were offering to people, they were cutting edge, innovative and responsive in a way that statutory services simply couldn't be, and I think that is very very important. I also believe that the Third Sector shouldn't give the impression that a strong motivation in terms of values is only found in the Third Sector. I think that is extremely insulting to people who work everyday in public services in one kind or the other in the statutory sector, many of whom are equally passionate about the values which drive those services.
	So for me this topic and this new opportunity to be Minister for Care Services, my third job in Government, bring together some of the things that have been most formative in terms of my political beliefs and in terms of the opportunities that I have had.
	The last job I had was at the Treasury as Economic Secretary to the Treasury, and I was able in that role to lay the foundations of the review that is under way, in terms of looking at the relationship between Government and the state and the Third Sector in the context of the next CSR. The chancellor has made it very clear is very clear he wants to see a root and branch review of that relationship and we are currently conducting the largest consultation that has ever taken place in this area.
	Just this Monday I was in Cambridge speaking to- and, more importantly, listening to -? representatives of the Third Sector in the East of England. I can tell you, from having been in the Treasury for a year,? the Chancellor almost on a weekly basis was engaging me in a conversation on the Third Sector and the challenges and issues that were facing the Third Sector; and I think that is a very important statement to make in terms of the people at the top of the Party and the Government and their genuine commitment to this sector and its crucial role in the development of the kind of society this Government wants to create.
	In terms of my role in DH, we spend billions of pounds a year and I believe could make far better use than hitherto of the Third Sector in terms of the delivery of services. I am determined to make this happen, to move from rhetoric to reality; and we are going to deliver demonstrable, tangible examples of how things are going to change. I personally have taken over the chairmanship of the Third Sector Commissioning taskforce. In the past, in my view, the way the Third Sector has been involved has often been gimmicky initiatives involving small amounts of money, which frequently do not get to the heart of the problem.
	This taskforce however has been attempting to deal with some of the fundamental issues that face the Third Sector in our society, prior to today: commissioning, procurement, regulation and accreditation.
	There has been constructive discussion, particularly on the issue of commissioning, which everybody here will understand is vital to the improvement of the quality of services. Good commissioning - hearing the views of people, involving partners and focussed on outcomes - is essential to our reforms of health and social care. And good commissioning will also acknowledge what the Third Sector has to offer.
	Of course it is also essential that in every community and every part of the country the Third Sector engages with commissioners to make them fully aware of what they have to offer.
	A major success so far has been ensuring that the Third Sector is considered in all the reforms we are making to the social care and health system.
	It is absolutely essential in my view that we move the Third Sector from the margins of policy to the mainstreams of policy.
	We intend to publish the Taskforce report shortly. Actual publication won't see the end of the taskforce's work, but really the beginning of the most exciting phase, as we seek to ensure implementation.
	This issue of commissioning is very, very important, in my view: up and down the country there are people fulfilling commissioning responsibilities, who, frankly, do not have the skill set to commission services we want at the start of the 21st century and still have a mindset of commissioning services that were appropriate 20 or 30 years ago.
	We still have a mindset where commissioners look to the safe familiar tools rather than reaching out to innovative and imaginative solutions from any sector in terms of achieving outcomes for users and carers that we seek.
	This question of influencing commissioners and commissioning is absolutely at the heart of the whether we are able to remould our public services. Sometimes we talk about people with those kinds of roles within our public services: we think of highly paid, highly skilled individuals. Actually that is not always the case: sometimes people end up in commissioning roles without any experience, without any skills, without actually engaging in a debate about how their role is at the heart of changing the culture of configuration of services in any locality, so this question is very very important.
	We've also established a Social Enterprise Unit in the Department.
	It will be a hub of ideas, energy and support for social enterprises.? It will link to the ten new Strategic Health Authorities who will provide more localised support to social enterprises. This will be as part of their role in reforming the way services are provided in the community.?
	And of course it will also link to the overarching social enterprise team in the Office of the Third Sector, under Ed Miliband.? Having a dedicated unit in the Department of Health, in my view, will allow us to focus on helping social enterprise organisations to grow and flourish in the specialised environment of health and social care.
	The Unit will also establish the social enterprise fund promised by the White Paper, a fund to help new and growing social enterprises.? And it will be there to highlight and share best practice.
	One such example of that is an organisation called Local Care Direct, one of the largest providers of urgent healthcare services in the country.? Covering two million people in West Yorkshire, Local Care Direct is a not for profit social enterprise which is very much an integral part of the NHS family.
	A workforce of local GPs, specially trained nurses and even dental practitioners providing wide range of innovative services, going far beyond traditional out of hours cover.? For example, Local Care Direct provides services to local prisons and operates a drug advice line that ensures people get a next working day appointment with the relevant drug intervention teams.
	I hope that our Social Enterprise Unit will foster the development of more such businesses - both new social enterprises with something to offer health and social care, or existing providers who adopt the social enterprise model and its benefits, such as more involvement with the local community and greater flexibility to innovate.
	We particularly want to encourage social enterprise organisations that look at the whole spectrum of people's health and social care needs, with a view to providing holistic services.? And we will expect social enterprises to be working closely with partners, whether voluntary, statutory or private.
	I also want to talk about some concrete examples of what is happening out there, which I believe is beginning to make a difference.
	The Expert Patients Programme delivers high quality courses that help people with long term conditions manage those conditions better.? Key to the success of its approach was having the course led by a person who themselves had a long term condition.
	Because of its success, we want it to work on a far greater scale - delivering 100,000 course places a year rather than the present 12,000. So we want to liberate it to expand it and to innovate it by creating the first national Community Interest Company - or CIC - to be established in England. The Expert Patients Programme CIC will be better able to market its courses to commissioners.? It will also be able to develop exciting new approaches to self-management that will be more relevant to the young, ethnic minorities and other groups that the traditional NHS sometimes struggles to reach.
	The new Expert Patients Programme CIC will be a value based organisation.? It will operate as a business but with the principal goal of improving the lives of people with long-term health conditions.?
	We have taken what I believe is a good idea behind the Expert Patients Programme and are currently now developing an Expert Carers Programme that will help support the work by the 6 million carers who look after relatives and loved ones, often at a significant cost of their own health and well-being.?
	Exact details are being developed - however, we hope that this programme will be delivered through the third sector.? We intend to consult widely throughout the year as to the final shape of the programme. But the outcomes are clear. I expect that from next year training for carers to enable them to better care for themselves and those they assist, will be more widely available and of a consistently high quality across the country.
	Finally, another concrete example is one that will be announced later on today by the PM.
	If I want to keep my job I am not going to tell you what that announcement is going to be, but I believe it will be seen as very exciting and very significant.
	So colleagues, I believe this is a very exciting time for the future of social care and health care
	I believe the challenge is to achieve what people have spoken about over decades, which is the integration of health, not just with social care, but with other community care services. Forr too long we have had a separate siphon in terms of organisations that are all meant to be interacting to support users in our society.
	In a user's and carer's perspective it doesn't matter if the service comes from the NHS, the LA social services department and other departments of the LA, the Third Sector or indeed the private sector: what matters to users and carers is that they get a responsive service.



Conclusion
	I want to conclude with what I regard our mission is and how I believe we can make it a reality.? That mission is to ensure users and carers have access to services which meet their needs, maximise their quality of life, and offer them dignity and control.
	This mission will require us to enable the third sector to be equal partners in the design and delivery of services and advocates for those who lack a voice or who require a helping hand.? We must consign to history the notion that any organisation or professional, for that matter, has a right to provide soley on the basis of their status or historical monopoly.
	At the same time however we must maintain and develop public accountability for any service offered to the public and funded by the taxpayer.
	Partnership, a word that many of you will be familiar with. Partnership must be restored to the noble pursuit it should be rather than the tarnished diluted word it has all too frequently become.? Partnership should be for a purpose, focused on shared outcomes, authentic, with every partner treated with equal respect and value.
	National principles and worthy rhetoric enshrined in the Compact must become a reality in every Government Department, every community and every sector in every part of the country.? We and you didn't sign up to a postcode Compact.
	As we face the challenges of a rapidly changing nation in an ever changing world, let us renew and reinvigorate our commitment to each other.
	There is such a thing as society but society at its best has always been citizens, voluntary groups, businesses, trade unions and the state combining to achieve social justice and prosperity.
	Together I beleive we can change the world whether in the shanty towns of Africa, the disadvantaged neighbourhoods of Britain, or the leafy suburbs of middle England. Let us unite around our enduring values of equality of opportunity, service and community.
	Together let's make it happen
	Thank you

	I'm new to this forum and have a couple of questions.  First, I am currently a member of the United Methodist church.  I agree with a lot of the teachings and beliefs of the church, however I am finding that the congregations do not always follow the teachings.  After much reflection and many years of feeling drawn to quakerism, I have come to the conclusion that I AM a Quaker.  Unfortunately, there is no meeting house anywhere near where I live (there is an evangelical friends church but I don't agree with their teaching and practices).  My questions are:  can I be a Quaker without having attended a meeting?  What can I do about my isolation?  There is a meeting house just over an hour from me but cannot see making that trip on a weekly basis.


	Back to top		      



	
	AtlantaScott



Joined: 21 Aug 2002
Posts: 102
Location: Atlanta Georgia (Gwinnett County)
		Posted:  Fri Oct 6, 2006 7:26 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	Friend,


Thanks for sharing that!  Yes, it is possible...not ideal (how much in life or even if you had a Meeting nearby would be ideal however?)..but possible.  My suggestion is to research, read a lot here and books (Some suggestions are: A Quaker Reader by Jessamyn West, A Living Faith by Wilmer Cooper,  Quaker Spirituality (Douglas V. Steere), and that will keep you busy a while. Then research the various Branches and determine with which Yeary Meeting you are most in unity, (I would love to think you might decide that Conservative Friends---meaning conserving the original testimony and Christian faith of Quakers)---would be what you seek, but maybe that is not the case.  After that decision, then seek out the Monthly Meeting of that Yearly Meeting that best reflects what you seek. Many Conservative MM allow "affiliate" membership at a distance!  Some others may as well.  Friends World Committee on Consultation (at www.fwccworld.org) offers membership to scattered Friends as well I think.  You can relax and research now knowing that I guess, with my anwers and that of others, you are NOT alone!!!  Quakers are few in numbers in many areas....there may actually be a few in your area (other than the Evangelicals that you mentioned) that might can help.  You never know.  It might help to mention your location.  Maybe you are called for a purpose where you are, to start a worship group, or just to be there, and ocassionally attend Friends Gatherings when possible.  There are many chances to do so!  Let us know where you are (I forgot, you may have done that when you registered!) and that might help.  If "Conservative" seems to best fit you, let me know for more information.  If not, that's quite alright too and know that there are many resources here for all.  I am sure God will lead you where He wants and needs you now, and that's what counts!  Be encouraged!


-Scott in Atlanta GA

Last edited by AtlantaScott on  Mon Oct 23, 2006 8:31 pm; edited 2 times in total

	Pulpculture

		Posted:  Sat Oct 7, 2006 3:02 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	Quaker Online is a good starting point.





There are a couple of online Quaker setups.


	Back to top		      



	
	cigi104



Joined: 03 Oct 2006
Posts: 7

		Posted:  Sat Oct 7, 2006 7:58 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	Thank you Scott and Popculture.  I have been doing much research online and will look into the links and books you mentioned.  I'm not sure what "conservative" Quaker means.   I see myself as a Christ-centered Friend who sees the Bible as a guide for life but not to be taken literally - which is why the evangelical friends church would not suit me.  I look to Christ's words to guide me in my daily life - leading me to support peace and social-justice.  The United Methodist church is supposed to support these beliefs, however, I am finding that many members do not.  In addition, I feel like a phoney when involved in the various rituals of the church because I don't believe they are necessary.


	Back to top		      



	
	orPowers



Joined: 25 Aug 2006
Posts: 133
Location: Medford, OR
		Posted:  Sat Oct 7, 2006 9:15 am    Post subject: community	   
	

	Scott has some very good suggestions, including the idea that you may have a fellowship of like minded believers that meets in your home, or one of the others.  Such contacts may come as you express your convictions to people with whom you share interests.  Another question is whether you could participate in a community with which your views are not in total agreement (have you got siblings, and do you always agree with them?)  For instance, on the question of ceremonies the point is whether you bring to the ceremony the capability of incorporating the spiritual truth that animates it, or whether the thought that it is simply not "necessary" keeps you from appreciating what it represents.  On Evangelical Friends, I would suggest that their perception of the place of scripture need not impinge in yours, so long as you are in unity in the love of the Lord and how it is expressed in Meeting.  They might exclude you based on your views, but there is no need to exclude them before you even find out if there is a basis for community.  "He drew a circle that kept me out, but love and I had the wit to win, we drew a circle that took him in."  It distresses me that we seem to have a mindset that we have to be in perfect agreement on everything in order to have "community."
_________________
Romans 8:38-39

	Welcome Firend cigl 104





I would a little to all the good things offered here, by others.





It is quite common in the UK for Friends to belong to their original church, as well as the Society-they call it dual membership in Britian.  


You might decide to attend the meeting, that is an hour away, at a regualr interval that works for you. Say fortnightly, monthly or wahtever.  That would  give  a structure. Other sundays you could worship at your church if so led, and  / or  at home alone.  Sometimes, I form an intention, in my mind to   link uip with a MfW happening at this time.  Thus, present in spirit. Also reading a line or 2 from one of the Books of Discipline, or the Advices & Queries, which can aid Worshipping when alone.





There is also an on-line Meeting for Worship --Google 'Meeting for Worship on-line U.K. ' and that should get you to the on-line meeting.





You may well find it useful.





with best wishes for your journey, Friend





Laurence

	I appreciate all the input.  As far as finding common ground for community, I find most of that within the methodist denomination.  Unlike evangelical friends, methodists do not take scripture literally but interpret it as a guide for our spiritual lives.  However, I'm more drawn to the friends more many other reasons, including simple living and silent prayer.  I find the prayers offered by the pastor and others during service to be distracting to my connection with God.  It is supposed to help us center but I can never get to that point because I'm too busy listening to the prayer rather than receiving God's messsage.  





As far as attending two places of worship, that does seem like a very good option for me.  As I already feel I have 2 churches (I moved to VA from FL and occasional attend service in FL), one more would be a blessing!

That sounds so much like the way I was back in 199? before I flipped out of church! However, you are fortunate that you have Quaker info to look forward, too. I learned the hard knocks way (of which I am top of the class). Now I realize that my biggest - very biggest - mistake was looking at the people! which caused me in having lost the best friend I had (my dear God, my Savior, my Lord) - and it was like a kid being lost in the crowd in a foreign country with your parent right behind you all the time!





If i had it to do all over again, which I don't and have to accept things as is, I would run immediately to my great God and cling like the dickens. and, pray for those (lost) people that I was struck by in total shock(?).
