				HAMPSHIRE COUNTY COUNCIL A WINNER IN UK E-GOVERNMENT NATIONAL AWARDS


				

					
					


 PRESS RELEASE ISSUED ON BEHALF OF THE E-GOVERNMENT NATIONAL AWARDS 
  Hampshire County Council has won a prestigious award which highlights and praises the best strategies, teams and people in UK e-Government. The e-Government National Awards 2005 were presented on the evening of 25th January, at a high level dinner at the Savoy Hotel attended by 440 senior council and civil service leaders. 
  The awards are a yardstick for UK excellence in e-Government - and highlights the massive benefits to the UK of services like Directgov, online vehicle licensing, school pupil e-assessment at Key stage 3, and numerous council e-services improving lives in localities across the UK 
  Hampshire County Council was a joint winner in the Efficiency category with its Hantsnet service. The project transformed Hampshire County Council's computer services and network architecture, in support of the County's modernisation programme, and provided an efficient and effective platform for ICT based services which already generates savings of at least £4m annually. 
  Departments have access to a cost effective set of systems for supporting new/more efficient ways of working - helping with the delivery of better and more available services for citizens. With the last of the County's mainframes being switched off in April 2005 Hampshire County Council now has a highly efficient infrastructure to deliver effective high availability services. 
  The thin client technology employed has made supporting and upgrading applications on thousands of desktops in hundreds of locations far less expensive and time-consuming. 
  e-Government is a prime enabler for transformation of the way that central and local Government interact and communicate with UK Citizens and local authorities were 97% e-enabled by the start of the year. 
  Councils, central government departments, non-departmental public bodies and National e-Government Projects are all among the Finalists - showing a great diversity and spread of achievement in e-Government right across the UK. 
  Jim Murphy MP, Parliamentary Secretary at the Cabinet Office said: 
 "e-Government is one of the most important ways the Government can deliver public services reform. We are committed to developing Government IT systems and services that make real and tangible improvements to the lives of British people and businesses. The e-Government National Awards are our way to recognise the best attempts to deliver on this commitment." 
  Jim Fitzpatrick MP - Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the 
 Office of the Deputy Prime Minister said: 
  "I'm delighted to see so many councils entering the e-Government National Awards. Local e-government has made enormous progress over the last five years, and this is shown by the number and high quality of the bids. " 
  Ian Watmore, Head of the Prime Minister's deliver Unit - and formerly Government CIO and head of e-Government at the Cabinet Office, said: 
  "The Cabinet Office e-Government Unit is proud to support the e-Government National Awards". 
  "For many government organisations, technology has fundamentally changed their relationship with citizens and businesses. Beyond putting services online this is the future of technology in Government - using IT to enable a wider transformation of the way Government works. There are many innovative services being provided across the public sector which very often don't get the publicity and reward that they deserve. I hope that these awards can play a part in addressing that." 
  "e-Government is a key tool in service transformation for central departments and local authorities - and will impact on the lives of all UK citizens", says Christopher Histed, founder of the e-Government National Awards and its organiser PublicTechnology.net, the online news source for the e-Government & public sector IT community. 
  The Government recently published its IT strategy, 'Transformational Government' - which promises a wide-ranging plan to transform and improve UK public services via IT and e-Government. 
  The government IT strategy has three key points: 
  1) Services enabled by IT must be designed around the citizen or business, not the provider, and provided through modern, co-ordinated delivery channels. This will improve the customer experience, achieve better policy outcomes, reduce paperwork burdens and improve efficiency by reducing duplication and routine processing, leveraging delivery capacity and streamlining processes. 
  2) Government must move to a shared services culture - in the front-office, in the back-office, in information and in infrastructure - and release efficiencies by standardisation, simplification and sharing. 
  3) There must be broadening and deepening of government's professionalism in terms of the planning, delivery, management, skills and governance of IT enabled change. This will result in more successful outcomes; fewer costly delivery failures; and increased confidence by citizens and politicians in the delivery of change by the public services. 
  The Prime Minister commissioned the strategy to seize the opportunity provided by technology to transform the business of government. Technology has a major part to play in the solutions to each of three major challenges which globalisation is setting modern governments - economic productivity, social justice and public service reform. Only a strategic view will enable the United Kingdom to use technology decisively and effectively across government to meet its national objectives. 
  In particular, the strategy was directed to provide overall technology leadership in three key areas: 
 * The transformation of public services for the benefit of citizens, businesses, taxpayers and front-line staff. 
 * The efficiency of the corporate services and infrastructure of government organisations, thus freeing resources for the front-line. 
 * The steps necessary to achieve the effective delivery of technology for government. 
  Notes to editors 
  1. The e-Government Unit (eGU) in the Cabinet Office has been tasked by the Prime Minister to 'ensure that IT supports the business transformation of Government itself so that we can provide better, more efficient, public services.' 
  2. The e-Government Unit (eGU) in the Cabinet Office are responsible for; 
 a. formulating information technology (IT) strategy and policy 
 b. developing common IT components for use across government 
 c. promoting best practice across government 
 d. delivering citizen-centred online services

		Department for Work and Pensions (DWP)


DWP is responsible for the Government's welfare reform agenda. It delivers support and advice through a network of local offices throughout England, Scotland and Wales, as well as providing phone and internet-based services. Its services are aimed at people of working age, pensioners, families and children, disabled people and employers. Key functions include:
	It is the lead department for disability rights and benefits for the disabled and their carers.


	Jobcentre Plus provides a range of services to link jobseekers to employers and help with claiming benefits for those who need them.


	Administers programmes like New Deal to aid unemployed people back to work.


	Provides support for those who are long-term sick or disabled, including benefits and assistance in finding work.


	The Pension Service supports pensioners by helping them to receive all they are entitled to. It helps those near retirement or planning for retirement to think about the right sort of pension provision.


	The Child Support Agency is a child support service, which aims to ensure that children whose parents do not live together are financially supported.

                                          	20/01/2001

                                                ASSEMBLY AGENDA NUMBER 55 


                                          I have often used this column to highlight the importance of finding ways to find out what young people think. Last Friday, Kim Howells and I put ourselves in the proverbial hotseat when we held a special “Children and Young People’s Advice Surgery” and invited local schools to send us clients. Three schools took up the invitation and our thanks to teachers at Cefn School in Glyncoch, Hawthorn and Coedylan for encouraging and accompanying our young clients. We were extremely impressed with the interest the young people showed in local and national issues. They wanted to ban hunting, were worried about student loans and wanted the redevelopment of Pontypridd to go ahead with a new swimming pool in the park. All age groups were worried about the rise of mindless vandalism, the amount of litter on our streets, and school buses. Teenagers in particular wanted “somewhere to go.” 

As a result of doing this surgery, Kim and I are keen to put more young people’s surgeries into our regular advice surgery calendar. On the back of the good ideas expressed by the young people of Pontypridd, I wanted to let you know that the Assembly is currently asking for people’s opinions on what kind of services should be provided for young people generally – from youth services to careers advice to smart cards. A group of experts from outside the Assembly have written a report called “Extending Entitlement” and we are particularly keen to have young people’s views on it. I know that some school councils have already discussed it and if you have an interest in improving services for young people, get in touch with my office and we will make sure that you have a copy of the report. Comments have to be in by the end of March, so there is plenty of time.

Happy birthday Pontypridd and District Housing Association (PDHA) - 21 years old this week. It’s not just a housing association providing houses for rent, but also helps older people who want to live at home with free confidential advice. It won a special award, Participation 2000, this year for working with homeless young people who helped build their own homes. Small, but beautiful! Congratulations to the staff and the management committee – particularly, the founder members. Have a good party!

	Sweet Success - Clean Energy from Old Waste
	 
	
		
Bacteria that can munch through confectionery and other food processing wastes to produce hydrogen could be a valuable source of energy in the future.

Professor Lynne Macaskie and her team at the University of Birmingham have used the hydrogen to generate clean electricity via a fuel cell.  

The technique could also provide the food industry with a useful outlet for the waste generated by their manufacturing processes, much of which is currently disposed of in landfill sites.


	
	Bacteria that can eat confectioney to produce hydrogen could be a valuable source of future energy

“Hydrogen offers huge potential as a carbon-free energy carrier,” says Professor Macaskie. “We’ve demonstrated a hydrogen-producing, waste-reducing technology that might be scaled-up in 5-10 years’ time for industrial electricity generation and waste treatment processes.”  

The research group are now planning a joint venture with an SME to improve the hydrogen yield further. 

They have also developed links with companies in Uganda and Canada that are interested in using the technology to convert sweet potato waste into hydrogen for cheap energy generation in Africa.

This research is an important part of the work underpinning a new £6.3 million hydrogen energy project funded by Advantage West Midlands. The £1.7 million EPSRC SCRATCH project (Supply Chain Research Applied to Clean Hydrogen) will develop the potential applications further.

Professor Macaskie spent time working in industry as a result of Royal Society/EPSRC Industry Fellow. She says, “The industry fellowship has been very beneficial in setting up enduring links and in seeing how the other sector operates.”

Sacred Texts: 13th century Talmud

 

 Main | Turning the Pages | Features | Highlights tour | Showcases | What's on | Visit us


	
		

		

		

	




	Home > Online Gallery > Sacred texts > 13th century Talmud


	

	
		

		
			
				13th-century Talmud

				This is an exceptionally rare item: a Talmud from the Middle Ages that has somehow escaped the public burnings suffered by most of the other books of Jewish law at the time. Fortunately, it has survived unmutilated and uncensored.  

				Enlarged image Zoomable high-resolution image

			          					

					
						Babylonian Talmud Origin unknown, c.13th–14th century.  Gemara 

BL Add. MS 25717, ff. 72v-73

						Copyright © The British Library Board  

						

			  

					What is the Talmud?

				The Talmud contains the Mishnah (oral law) and the Gemara ('Completion', written in Aramaic). The Mishnah was the first great creation of the rabbis, who were not clergy but came from all walks of life. It is a large collection of sayings, arguments and counter-arguments that touch on virtually all areas of life. 

				Over the three centuries following the compilation of the Mishnah, the rabbis added enormously to it with the Gemara: what they called a 'sea' of learning, using stories about both biblical personalities and their own lives, sober legal arguments and fanciful imaginings of the world of old and the world to come. They wrote it all down in multiple volumes that go under the name Talmud, 'Teaching'. 

				Why is this a 'Babylonian'  Talmud?

				The Talmud developed in two major centres of Jewish scholarship: Babylonia and Palestine. The Jerusalem or Palestinian Talmud was completed c.350, and the Babylonian Talmud (the more complete and authoritative) was written down c.500, but was further edited for another two centuries. The Talmud served as the basis for all codes of rabbinic law. 

From the Palestinian tradition of Jewish worship came the Ashkenazi rite used in Western and Eastern Europe and Russia. From the Babylonian tradition came the Sephardi rite followed in Spain, Portugal, North Africa, and the Middle East. Both rites, as well as some others, are still practised in Orthodox Jewish communities worldwide.
 
In genealogical discussions, people often use the term Ashkenazi and Sephardic to describe Jews who come from the respective regions. 

What is  the  significance of the Talmud?

Getting to grips with a Talmudic text can be demanding. While it is possible to read a page of the Bible in a matter of minutes, depending on the difficulty, a page of Talmud may take an hour or considerably more to go through with understanding. Traditionally it is studied with a partner or 'friend' in order to recreate the internal arguments and make sure that the subject in question, whether marriage, business ethics, capital punishment, property law or dietary regulations, has been examined from every conceivable angle. This kind of study leads to sharpness of mind, but also creates an intense community of shared ideas and visions. 

Along with its companion literature, the Midrash (multiple collections of interpretations of the Bible, much like the interpretations and sermons on their own Scriptures by Christians and Muslims), the Talmud ensured that male Jews, who engaged in this study their whole lives, and their womenfolk, who were taught the stories (but not the legal material) in more popular form, were armoured against an often unfriendly outside world by their own internal world of values.

Why is this manuscript so rare?

During the Middle Ages the Talmud was the target of relentless condemnation, vilification and censorship by the Christian Church. Vicious hostility to its allegedly offensive and blasphemous contents led to frequent public burnings, the first in Paris in 1242. 

As a result, very few complete manuscripts of the Talmud have survived, and the remaining fragmentary ones are also rather scarce. 

What do these pages show?

This manuscript (in square Ashkenazi hand) is an exceptionally rare specimen, which, fortunately, has not been censored or mutilated. 

It shows the end of tractate Arakhin ('Valuations'), which deals with issues relating to the upkeep of the sanctuary, and the start of tractate Keritot ('Excisions'), which discusses sins that incur divine punishment.

      The Future of Peer Review

    Posted by Michael Jubb, 08 May 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		A report – Peer Review: its Present and Future States - has recently been published of the proceedings of a conference organised by the European Science Foundation, the European Heads of Research Councils, and the Czech Science Foundation, and held in October last year in Prague. The conference brought together some 150 delegates from across Europe, the US and Asia, including publishers as well as funding bodies and research institutions. 

  A major theme of the conference appears to have been a concern, expressed by Sir John O’Reilly, the former Chief Executive of the EPSRC in the UK, that peer review systems tend to be conservative in assessing the quality of innovative research proposals; and there was much discussion about how to ensure that pioneering research is not jeopardised by such conservatism. There was also some interesting discussion about the need to adopt innovative approaches in the peer review process itself, including video-enhanced discussions and online discussions; but also about the need to minimise the burdens that the peer review system places on reviewers.

   

  The conclusion seems to have been that there is a need for “a strategic evaluation at a more conceptual level, not of a specific mechanism, but of the underlying principles and ideas………..Continuously monitoring the peer review system on which the quality of science so heavily depends will contribute to its improvement.” Who will take on the job of providing such an evaluation, and such a monitoring role, is an interesting question.

      Research Data and Laboratory Notebooks

    Posted by Michael Jubb, 04 May 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		There’s an interesting and rather strong editorial in Nature this week which complements the consultation draft we issued a few weeks ago of principles relating to the stewardship of research data.

It urges that research institutions and funders should show leadership by promoting the use of electronic laboratory notebooks, and provide the infrastructure support earmarked for the development and upkeep of notebook systems. The rationale is twofold: first to protect against error and fraud; and second, to allow the sharing and archiving of data, with each notebook allocated a unique identifier.

As Nature puts it, by providing support for such systems, concerns about the loss of data can be assuaged, and the rigour and transparency of publicly-funded research will be improved. It will be interesting to see how the funding agencies react to this proposal.

      E-research skills for librarians

		Here's a bit of news that nicely complements the recent publication of the RIN-CURL report on researchers' use of library services.  Under the auspices of the CURL / SCONUL taskforce on e-research, there will be a workshop on 14-15 June, in Edinburgh (hosted by the National e-Science Centre) on 'Support for e-research - Filling the library skills gap'.  This promises to be an interesting opportunity for university librarians or information professionals to hear, from expert practitioners, about developments in e-research and the developing infrastructure of support.

The event will explore current developments and their impact upon library support and services. How will services be re- engineered to interface seamlessly with researchers' changing work processes? Who are librarians' partners in developing support structures for e-Research? How can libraries assist with support for the use of distributed networks and the management of data generated by this research? Very timely issues indeed for a rapidly-changing environment.

Places at the workshop are limited, so it's advisable to book as soon as possible.

And if you haven't yet seen the RIN-CURL report referred to at the beginning - which has a thing or two to say about e-research - please don't hesitate to do so now!  It's already been downloaded over 2500 times, so it's obviously a good read...

      Eight reasons why I've axed our "chat thingy"

    Posted by James Brown, 02 May 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		

Right. It's over. It's gone. Finito. 

There'll be no tears, however, because it turns out few people were interested in using our plugoo chat widget. 

It sat in the right-hand sidebar of this blog, and gave you the chance to have a quick and easy chat with me if I was at my desk. 

I'm going to maintain that it was a useful experiment, and it certainly displayed our commitment to communication. It was sincere - I was eagerly awaiting the chance to talk to any visitors, help with any problems they had, discuss something we'd written or done.

Despite the significant number of readers this blog is delighted to have, few of you decided to use the plugin. So here's some ideas I have about why. 

	You didn't see it
	You didn't know what it was
	You weren't interested in using it
	You didn't feel you had anything to say
	You read the blog via our rss feed so never came across it
	You didn't want to have your conversation in view of everyone else (it's actually a private 1-1, but this wasn't obvious)
	You couldn't use it because your network/firewall wouldn't allow it
	You had something to say, but there were more apprioate methods of saying it. 


Or was it something else? Let me know.

      Putting the listserv out of its misery

    Posted by James Brown, 26 Apr 2007

    

	
		2 comments				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		At my university, anybody could set up an email listserv in about 45 seconds. And there were thousands of them. I spent a brief time as a list administrator for the college football team - it was meant to be used to organise fixture times and squad details, but banter and jokes dominated the content after only a couple of weeks.

 The relevant and the not-so-relevant were both useful features (think team-spirit etc), but a significant minority were frustrated with all the "noise," and wanted out. It was a hassle taking off people individually (who would get quickly irate if you didn't), and then contacting them individually. It was impossible to remember everybody's individual preferences. In short, the system didn't work. 

By using a blog search engine that Phil Bradley mentioned on his blog, I came across a "libraries community" in the blog-land that is livejournal. It has over 1,700 members. One thread that caught my attention was called "Putting the liserv out of its misery." Here are some choice quotes:

I am not implying that a subject discussion forum itself is a bad idea, or that the discussions aren't valuable.. but the listserv seems to be a community-facilitating technology that is well, just so last century.



Wouldn't it be easier to set up a space where subscribers could actually follow full threads and not be inundated by avalanches of emails?.



It seems like you should subscribe to the digest versions of these lists.



Harnessing RSS feeds will be the swaying point, if anything, becuase now you can have the communication come to you.



I use rules, filters, and search to sort out my email overload and go through the interesting ones when I have time. What's the problem?



Seeing as email is still one of the preferred methods of receiving information - and that people have developed ways of coping with the deluge - I've added a new form in the left-hand column of this blog. If you so desire, you can subscribe to the RIN Team Blog by email update.

							Tags: RIN Team Blog | rss 
 
			








  
      Taxonomy, Folksonomy, Teamsonomy, Institutionomy!

    Posted by James Brown, 23 Apr 2007

    

	
		2 comments				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		Two things happening a week today: 1) plenty of time to register for our big event, and 2) the trial period for our plugoo chat plugin (in the right-hand sidebar) is ending, so do take the opportunity now to say hello! 

Right. I'm going to go ahead and make the assumption that we all know what I mean by the word taxonomy. It's the practice or technique of classification. Right? So you could, for example, apply a classification to the pages on this website. This page has been classified with the tags "data" and "internet."

 As I've mentioned previously, taxonomies online can be radically different to traditional cataloguing. The difference is in the vocabulary - catalogues use a controlled vocabulary like the Dewey Decimal System or the Library of Congress Subject Headings; whereas websites let the amateur choose the keywords. 

I'm sure you've also heard the term folksonomy, which is simply the process of letting the multitude choose the tags. For example, what if I gave you the chance to classify this very blog post. You'd probably choose some different tags to me. If hundreds of people added their own choice of tags to every page, we'd end up with a pretty unique cataloguing system for this website. You'd likely stumble across some pages you weren't bargaining for. 

For the RIN website here, we use what I'd like to call a teamsonomy. I sat down and drew together 30 or so keywords, then my colleagues looked through it and made some suggestions. Then it was settled. A combination of the tax- and the folk-, I suppose. Each time you make a new page/blog post, you choose which tag to apply. But then when a new colleague joined: "you don't have a "research" tag! - she pointed out.  

Suddenly it dawned on me - we had nothing more than a controlled vocabulary. So I'm now working on a way to let my colleagues (every now and then) add new tags to our list on the fly. I think teamsonomy is a fair enough description.

What would happen, however, if we had a much larger team? What if it was an entire institution? Who has control of the list, and who should...or shouldn't?!



I'd love to hear from anyone who's been thinking about it.

		We have just learned that the OECD Council agreed in December last a recommendation to Member Countries on access to research data arising from public funding (which is taken to mean data obtained through research conducted by government agencies or departments, or conducted using public funds provided by any level of government).

 The Council’s decision essentially gives the status of a formal recommendation to the guidelines produced by a working group that was established following an earlier Ministerial Declaration on access to research data in 2004. The guidelines are based around the principles set out in that declaration: openness, transparency, legal conformity, protection of intellectual property, formal responsibility, professionalism, interoperability, quality and security, efficiency, and accountability. 

We have taken these guidelines into account in the consultation draft statement of principles and guidelines on the stewardship of research data that we issued earlier this month. It seems a little odd that the OECD has not given any publicity to the Council recommendation: we could not find any reference to it on the webpages of the Science and Technology Directorate. But the formal terms of the recommendation are that member countries should

take into consideration the Principles and Guidelines on Access to Research Data from Public Funding ………… as appropriate for each Member country, [and] develop policies and good practices related to the accessibility, use and management of research data



This adds force to the need to address the kinds of issues that we set out in our recent paper, and we shall be interested to see reactions and responses to it in this light.

		The Read/Write Web blog recently ran a competition for tickets to a big web conference. The challenge: define "web 3.0." 

As you read this you might be rolling your eyes either in despair, confusion or exhaustion. But bear with me, because it's worth glimpsing the not-too-distant future. And as I'll explain, the tools that might use this technology are even nearer . So -  the winners were as follows:

	The Humorous definition winner: "Web 3.0 will complete my sentences."
	The Serious definition winner: "Web 3.0 – a decentralized asynchronous me."
	The Editor's Choice winner: "Warning: This comment is BETA."




 Laura Cohen, at her blog Library 2.0: An Academic's Perspective gives a run down of what might happen to libraries and academics if each of them came true. For example, being able to complete my sentences would make writing academic papers (and blog entries!) an awful lot easier.

What Laura really got me thinking about, though, was the serious definition. How far away is it? One tool that she suggests could harness the concept would be a sophisticated RSS reader:

With good metadata on the source end, and sophisticated customization and learning on the agent end, I might ultimately get the filtered RSS content that I want.



Well perhaps this is actually much nearer than we realise. My desktop reader lets me create smart feeds by pre-searching for specific words, phrases, tags and authors; flagging up relevant content for me. I haven't tried to use it to exclude content, but it would be a relatively easy tweak to use it as a filter rather than as a highlighter.

I realise the software isn't making any attempt to understand the content, so it's rather crude and not very 3.0! But perhaps the next step is for it to analyse attention data, like which articles I delete and which I click through; then apply some clever filters appropriately. It looks like Google is on the way to doing this.

 And then there's tools like Particls. Formerly called Touchstone, this is a "personalised news and alert service" which monitors the internet, your feeds and other information like your calendar and emails, learns which are important to you, and alerts you in different ways according to their importance. And I can't go 5 minutes without mentioning Yahoo Pipes these days. 

Maybe we're closer than we realise.
